awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Scalability and Reliability for Network Communication Infrastructure in Smart Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
As the first major milestone and the fundamental step of the overall smart grid roadmap, an advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) is a system that senses, collects and analyzes data on energy usage and power quality from smart meters, and communicates with metering devices on request or on schedule. In spite of many recent research activities on smart grid communication infrastructure, scalability and reliability of communication architectures in smart grid AMI are still not well-addressed yet, even though they are two of the most important issues in this field. These have seriously hampered the development and deployment of effective communication technologies to smart grid field. Moreover, there is still a critical gap in the knowledge base to understand the interactions and the tradeoffs of scalability and reliability, and to design the best performance metrics in smart grid AMI.

This project investigates the challenging issues of emerging communication network design in smart grid, and study scalability and reliability aspects and their interactions in AMI. The proposed research aims at analysis and design of scalable architectures for advanced metering infrastructures in the wide area network level, and designs reliable communications for energy efficient self-sustaining neighborhood area networks. The approaches include identifying and addressing the new challenges in the scalability and reliability design for smart grid communications with a large amount of data and different communication requirements, designing novel algorithms for optimal deployment of neighborhood area networks, and summarizing design strategies and principles for scalable and reliable end-to-end smart grid communications under various scenarios. This project introduces novel network design strategies and principles to achieve scalable and reliable network communication infrastructure that can handle a tremendous amount of AMI smart metering data in real-time. The research efforts conducted in this project will advance scientific understanding in the field of network communication infrastructure in smart grid, and have a significant impact on the design of scalable and reliable smart grid AMI systems. The outcomes of the project will foster the transition of our society into a more energy efficient and sustainable future. The project incorporates an education plan that engages underrepresented students.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the theoretical foundations to support the design of next generation scalable and reliable smart grid communication infrastructure. The proposed research aims at analysis and design of scalable architectures for advanced metering infrastructures in wide area network level, and design reliable communications for energy efficient self-sustaining neighborhood area networks. The approaches include identifying and addressing the new challenges in the scalability and reliability design for smart grid communications with large amount of data and different communication requirements, designing novel algorithms for optimal deployment of neighborhood area networks, summarizing design strategies and principles for scalable and reliable end-to-end smart grid communications under various scenarios.

The project advanced the field of network communication infrastructure in smart grid, by the comprehensive study of the scalable and reliable communication architectures in AMI, which played a most significant role in shaping the future of smart grid. The research introduced novel network design strategies and principles to achieve scalable and reliable network communication infrastructure which can handle tremendous amount of AMI smart metering data in real-time.

During the four years of the project, the project team investigated two of the most challenging issues of emerging communication network design in smart grid, and studied scalability and reliability aspects and their interactions in advanced metering infrastructures (AMI). The project team proposed a novel framework of comprehensive study on AMI communications in smart grid, at two network architecture levels - wide area network (WAN) level and neighborhood area network (NAN) level. In wide area network level, the project team investigated several alternative scalable architectures for deploying AMI, and formulated optimal network design models with network deployment cost and network management cost as the objectives, in terms of scalability of the network communication infrastructures, and studied the performance of the smart grid communication systems in each of the communication architectures. In neighborhood area network level, the project team further developed reliable and energy efficient self-sustaining network design strategies and principles, so that neighborhood area networks can fit into the whole wide area network level to realize a fully scalable and reliable AMI network communication infrastructure for smart grid. More specifically, various research activities were conducted:

-   Scalability study on AMI communication architectures

-   Scalability analysis on AMI communication infrastructures

-   Optimal deployment of AMI communication infrastructure

-   Optimal self-sustaining wireless NAN design framework

-   Optimum number of gateways & gateway data access point deployment problems

-   Reliability and global uplink transmission power efficiency

-   Deployment of cost-effective, scalable and reliable communication infrastructures in smart grid

Computer simulations were developed to evaluate the performance and tradeoffs and validate the theoretical results for scalable and reliable smart grid communication infrastructure. As part of the comprehensive study, theoretical results to achieve optimal performance for scalable and reliable smart grid communication infrastructure, as well as practical engineering design rules and guidelines for implementation and deployment of scalable and reliable smart grid communication infrastructure, were obtained in the series of studies above.

The research activities of this project have significantly revolutionized the field of network communication infrastructures in smart grid, and have a significant impact on design of scalable and reliable smart grid AMI systems. The outcomes of the project will foster the transition of our society into a more energy efficient and sustainable future.
